channel.title: Book Notes on Rob's Notes
channel.description: Recent content in Book Notes on Rob's Notes

item.title: The Great Mental Models: Volume 1
item.description: I was introduced to The Knowledge Project by AJ last year during one of our 1-1 walks around the campus.

item.title: 21 Lessons for the 21st Century
item.description: I read this book on the way to and during the Alaska Trip that we took during last winter (2019).

item.title: Factfulness: Ten Reasons We're Wrong About the World—and Why Things Are Better Than You Think
item.description: I read this book on the way back from our Alaska Trip during our Anniversary.

item.title: Of Love and Other Demons
item.description: There are some novels that start slowly, and build up momentum as we progress through the story.

item.title: Blink - The Power of Thinking Without Thinking
item.description: I like the writing style of Malcom Gladwell. With enchanting short real-life stories and fascinating anecdotes, he takes you right into the book, to a different world where you are a student who is observing and studying the behavior of the people in different parts of the world, effortlessly moving to and fro through different periods of time.

item.title: The One Thing
item.description: The ONE Thing: The Surprisingly Simple Truth Behind Extraordinary Result by Gary Keller with Jay Papapsan

item.title: Functional Thinking
item.description: For someone who has been doing Java programming and reading through lot of OO codebase for over a decade, functional programming is truly a paradigm shift.

item.title: The End of Power
item.description: Mark Zuckerberg posts a public challenge/goal for himself at the beginning of every year and in 2015 it was to read a new book every two weeks.

item.title: Introduction to Data Mining
item.description: “Introduction to Data Mining” by Pang-Ning Tan, Michael Steinbach and Vipin Kumar has been recommended to me as a great book to learn about Data Mining.

item.title: 7 Habits of Highly Effective People
item.description: There are many books that when I think back on them, I have this lingering feeling that either due to reading quickly or not taking notes, I didn’t really take in the full essence of the book.

item.title: My Cousin Rachel
item.description: 6/17 It was Krishna’s wedding. Krishna, my closest pal during childhood; my first best friend (first best friend !

item.title: Makar Chudra
item.description: The story starts with Makar , an aged gypsy conversing with the author.

item.title: The King's General
item.description: The “The Kings General” is unlike any novel that I’ve read.
